div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.

div.head: The Artesian Boring and Prospecting Company
CABINET NOT TO RESIGN.
DISSOLUTION DEFERRED.
div.p: It is understood that the Cabinet has decid- ed not to resign.

The meeting of the Cabinet lasted two hours. It is stated that the decision of the Government was largely influenced by the knowledge that the Liberals would not accept office prior to disoIution, and, therefore, until Parliament meets again, it defers resigning or dissolving for a few weeks, thus avoiding at the same time an election at Christmastide and the neceisity of a shortlived interim government.
Mr. Balfour has left town until Monday. He is not going to Sandringham. The Cabinet will meet again on the 1st proximo. (Reuter)

div.head: HOME RULE FOR IRELAND.
C.B.’s POLICY
div.p: Speaking at Stirling, Sir Henry Campbell- Bannerman openly declared himself as being in favor of Home Rule for Ireland, saying that his conviction on this matter was stronger than ever. He advised the Nationalists, how- ever, to accept any instalment of representative control that might be offered, provided that it led up to a larger policy.
The newspapers continue to take Mr. Bal- four's resignation for granted. The “Morning Post” says that Mr. Chamberlain and not Mr. Baltour will lead the Unionists at the elections. (Reuter)

div.head: MOST-FAVORED NATION CLAUSE. BECOME OBSOLETE.
div.p: Lord Lansdowne, speaking here, said that the most-favored nation clause has become obsolete, and Great Britain must rely more upon contracts and bargains in which her interests are specially provided for.

He gave as an instance the new treaty with Persia replacing the old favored-nation arrange- ment. lf there should be any tampering with the Persian tariff in future, Great Britain will have to be consulted first. (Reuter)

div.head: THE PORTE DEFIANT.
THREAT OF FANATICAL OUTBREAK.
div.p: The Porte’s reply to the Powers is unusually defiant and closes with a veiled threat of a Mussulman outbreak if the pressure of the Powers in favor of Christians continues. (R.)

div.head: SIR C. HARDINGE AT THE FOREIGN OFFICE.
div.p: Sir C. Hardinge, Ambassador at St. Peters- burg, replaces Sir Thomas Sanderson, of the Foreign Office, who is retiring. (Reuter)

div.head: THE COURT.
div.p: Queen Alexandra and the King of Greece will go to Sandrigham to-day, where they will be joined by the King. (Reuter)

div.head: ZEMSTVOS CONGRESS.
div.p: The congress of delegates of the Zemstvos has voted in favor of direct suffrage. (Havas)

div.head: ADMIRAL RODJESTVBNSKY.
div.p: Admiral Rodjestvensky has left Vladivostok.

div.head: Deschizeaux Beautifying Rooms
div.p: AMERICAN Graduate Masseuse treats wrin- kles, enlarged pores and all facial blemishes permanently removed, face beautified and rejuvenated. Expert manicure and skilful chy- ropody.
6 Rue Cherif Pacha.
26754-3 Telephone 89.

div.p:
Surveyor and Contractor in shipping. Takes
charge of Engines and Boilers. Undertakes
repairs of same, guaranteeing success. First
class references. Address: Rue el Warsha,
Maison Gabriel, ALEXANDRIA

div.head: Khedivial Accession Fetes.
div.p: The third list of subscriptions to the fund for tho celebration of the Khedive’s Accession Day brings the total up to L.E. 350.

div.head: New Khedivial Palace.
div.p: The Khassa Khedivial has purchased a palace in Cairo, belonging to Princess Faikan Hanem, as a residence for the Khedive’s sons.

div.head: Erratum.
div.p: The list of inspectors assigned to the various provinces, appearing in our issue of Thursday, should, of course, have been headed “Ministry of the Interior."

div.head: Suez Canal.
div.p: Ten vessels passed through the Canal on the 21st inst., of which 7 were British, 2 German, 1 French. The total receipts from the 1st to the 21st inst. were frs. 7,177,394.61.

div.head: Charity Performance.
div.p: An entertainment for the benefit of the orphan school of the Sisters of St. Vincent de Paul will be given to-morrow at the African Mission, Choubrah. M. de la Bouliniere will preside and a very good programme is promised.

div.head: Egyptian Money Market.
div.p: Messrs. H. de Vries and Boutigny, stock and share brokers, Cairo, publish a very detailed circular daily on the business of the stock market. This circular, which contains also a great deal of financial information, is sent gratis on application. [Advt.]

div.head: Coal Imports.
div.p: From the 1st of January to the 23rd of No- vember 974,918 tons of coal were imported into Egypt. Wales sent 526,310. Newcastle 221,413, Scotland 118,203, Yorkshire 72,586, and other places 36,406 tons. During the cor- responding period of 1904 954,081 tons were received.

div.head: American Diplomacy.
div.p: President Roosevelt has decided that in future Ambassadors, Ministers, and attaches must know some other language besides English (see newspapers). A knowledge of languages is indispensable in all careers. Berlitz Schools of Languages: 26, Rue de l’Egliso Copte. Alexandria,and 1 ShariaKame’, Cairo. [Advt.]

div.head: Big Fee for Suez Canal.
div.p: The Navy Department at Washington has learned that the Suez Canal Company will charge from £4,000 to £5,000 for the passage of the Philippine dry dock, now being built in Cheaspeake Bay. The deck will begin its voyage, under tow, in December, and is ex- pected to reach the Philippines in four months.

div.head: The Abbas Helmy Fire.
div.p: This morning the case of Monferrato and the Alexandria Gas Company came on for hearing at the Mixed Tribunals, Alexandria. The case arose out of tho circumstances connected with the fire at the Abbas Helmy Theatre last year. Judgment will be given in a week’s time.

div.head: Distinguished American Visit.
div.p: Mr. Bryan, the American Democratic politi- cian, and at one time candidate for the Pre- sidency, is probably, paying a visit to Egypt this season. An American contemporary re- marks:—"Mr. Bryan should make a long and contemplative study of the Sphinx in Egypt. It may give him a pointer on the game in Democratio politics after his return.”

div.head: Moslem Fete.
div.p: The Moslem benevolent society will give a fete on Tuesday next at the Esbekieh Gardens, Cairo, under the patronage of H.H. the Khedive. The gardens will be open at 3 p.m. and we are promised a great display of fire- works, with dances, singing, fireworks, and all kinds of music, till the small hours of the morning, while an Arabic drama will be staged at the Opera House at 8.30 p.m.

div.head: A Princess as Guardian.
div.p: A native contemporary states that the Princess Nazli Hanem has agreed to act as guardian to her brother, Prince Aly Bey Fadel. Before accepting this post her Highness stipulated that her brother should have nothing to do with the management of his finances, and she has authorised M. R. Suares to deal with his affairs together with Djaafar Bey, son of Fakhri Pasha, counsel to the Princess’s Daira.

div.head: HOTEL D’AMERIQUE.
div.p: This morning the case of Adda v. Rosins di Bella came on for hearing before Judge Eeman in the Mixed Civil Court at Alexandria. This was an appeal against the judgment of the Mixed Summary Court, which we published a few weeks ago. The appellant has purchased the building and site known as the Hotel d’Amerique at Alexandria from Mr. Selim Sabounghi, and brought an action against Mrs. Rosina di Bella, the tenant, for resiliation of her lease on the grounds that she had need the hotel for improper purposes although it was specified in the contract that it should simply be need as an hotel-restaurant.
Maltre Levi Cuzzer on behalf of Mr. Adda declared that the Hotel d’Amerique was a public scandal, and protested against the judg- ment of the Summary Court.

Maltre Guidotti, on behalf of Mrs. Rosina di Bella, declared that Mr. Adda had asked £175 per annum from his client as a permit for her to renew the contract for the hotel. The lady in question had agreed to pay £110 per annum instead of £80, as arranged in the existing contract, which ends on 31st Jannary, 1907. But as she would not pay more than £110 the appellant said he would oblige her to quit.
Judgment will be given shortly.

div.head: LORD CURZON AT SUEZ.
PROCEEDING TO CAIRO.
div.p: Lord and Lady Canon and suite are ex- pected to reach here this afternoon on board the Royal Indian Marine steamer Dufferin. On arrival here they will proceed to Cairo and join the S.S. Mongolia at Port Said later on for Marseilles.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: On Thursday night H.H. the Khedive left Koubbeh for Cairo and was present at the religious ceremony of tho Leilet El Kadr, in the Citadel mosque. With his Highness were the Ministers and Under Secretaries of State, the Governor of Cairo, Ghazi Mukhtar Pasha, Zeki Pasha and the civil and military mem- bers of the Khedivial household, the director general of the Wakfs Administration, the ulema, and numerous natives of high rank.The mosque was most brilliantly illuminated.

Yesterday his Highness, with the Ministers, visited the mosque of Amr. On his arrival the 3rd Battery fired the usual salvoes while the guard of honor drawn from the 6th Battalion presented arms. The Khedive entered the mosque, which had been decorated for the occasion, accompanied by the Grand Mufti on his right and H.E. Abdel Halim Pasha Assem on his left. The usual military honors were paid on the departure of his Highness.
Yesterday evening the Khedive, after giving several audiences, offered an iftar to the merchants of Cairo.
To-day his Highness will preside over the Council of Ministers to be held at Abdeen Palace at 3 p.m.

div.head: ABBASSIEH LUNATIC ASYLUM.
div.p: Fresh sections are to be added to the Abbas- sieh Lunatic Asylum with a view to increasing the accommodation of the building. A sum of LE. 16,0000 will figure in the next Budget for these additions to the building, the construc- tion of which will be carried out under the supervision of Mr. Price, of the Public Health Department.

div.head: FREE STATE LANDS.
div.p: The cataloguing of Government Free Lands in the Fayoum province has begun. The catalogue of the Menoufieh province will be finished by the end of tho year. The catalogue of the Gharbieh province has just been com- pleted after five months’ work. The catalogue is very detailed and will not be finished for the whole of Egypt for four or five years.
Mr. J. T. Foxcroft, late of the Ministry of Public Instruction, has been appointed Finance Inspector to the Free State Lands Depart- ment.

div.head: STATE DOMAIN BONDS.
div.p: Egyptian State Domain Mortgage Bonds to the amount of £29,300 nominal capital have been drawn for payment at par on December 1. The drawing consists of all bonds (not pre- viously cancelled by the operation of the sink- ing fund) comprised in the series of numbers advertised.

div.head: HELOUAN.
div.p: The Tewfik Palace Hotel, Helonan, is evidently doing very well, and more people seem to appreciate the unique position of which this hotel has the advantage. The gardens, the comfortably sheltered terraces, palmhouses and grottoes make the place a veri- table paradise.

Amongst the many visitors now staying at the hotel aro Lord Robert Cecil, Lord Edward Cecil, Lady Cecil, Miss Dickinson, Baron and Baroness de Rosenwerth, Dr. Yeo- man, Dr. Hotchkiss, Mr. Parry, M. and Mrs. Greenwood, Mrs. Parrer, Misses Clemens, Mr. and Mrs. Phillips, Mrs. Hopkins, Mr. Wylie, M. Gazi, M. Hausch, Mrs. Lisener, Miss Uniake.
On Friday next an orchestra will perform during tea and dinner, for the benefit of those availing themselves of the "Tewfik week-end."

div.head: SUDAN GOVERNMENT.
div.p: The Sudan Government has decided to create a new moudirieh called Mongola, and L.E. 5,000 has been allotted for the purpose.
The Sudan Government has also decided to change the name of “Suakin Gouvernorat" to "Red Sea Gouvernorat”
It has been further decided to establish a new sanitary administration, to be called the “Local Provincial Service."

div.head: MARRIAGE AT MATARIEH.
div.p: The marriage of M. H. Parodi, professor at the Khedivieh School and chemist to H.H. the Khedive, and MIle Mathilde Bernard, daughter of M. Alex. Bernard Bey, Inspector to the Ministry of Public Instruction, and Mme Bernard, took place at the Matarieh chapel at 3.30 p.m. on Wednesday. After the marriage the parents of the bride gave a reception at their house at Matarieh, which was largely attended by the many friends of the bride and bridegroom.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. City of Cambridge Bailed from Malta last night and is due here on Tuesday at daybreak with passengers, mails, and general cargo.
The S.S. City of Khios sailed from Liverpool yesterday for Malta and Alexandria with passengers and general cargo.

div.head: THE SALT MONOPOLY
THE NEW AGREEMENT.
div.p: When the Government decided on the abolition of the salt monopoly it became neces- sary at the same time to settle the line of future policy in order to assure a regular supply of the article. On the one hand, the Government was desirous in the interests of all classes of the population and especially of the poorest, to ma- terially reduce the price of salt to the consumer. On the other hand it was reluctant to cause any unnecessary crisis in the affairs of the Salt & Soda Company, by the too abrupt termination of the monopoly which it has hitherto enjoyed, more especially as it believed that the com- pany, with its expenses and wide organisation, was in a position to continue to supply the public better than any one else.

Under the agreement which has been arrived at, the company waives its right to a six months' notice, and the monopoly ceases and determines on the 1st January next, when the retail price of salt will be reduced from 5 milliemes to 2 milliemes, while the Government on its part undertakes not to exploit its own salines, or to let them to others, for the space of six years. The poor will be free to piok np salt in the desert; but in order to avoid abuses it may be necessary to guard the more important salines, which will be done at the company’s expense.

By this arrangement it is hoped that not only will salt in Egypt be as cheap as any- where else in the world, but that no material injury will be done to the interests of the company whose shares are so largely held in this country.

div.head: SHIP ON FIRE IN PORT.
BEACHED NEAR BREAKWATER.
div.p: The S.S. Sardinia, of the Ellerman Line, which had just sent her redder ashore for repairs by Messrs. Watson & Co., was observed to be on fire in her forehold, stowed with cotton and rice, soon after noon yesterday. No flames were visible, but smoke was issuing from the port side through the ventilator cowl.

The ship was at once towed to the qua- rantine anchorage in the outer harbour, having the port steam fire-float , alongside. By 6 p.m., the smoke had ceased to issue after two hours incessant pumping, and it was hoped that the fire had been subdued. But, by 8 p.m. the smoke burst forth again and the pomps were set to work.

At 10 a.m. to-day it was decided to put the ship ashore on the bank under the breakwater, so that the hold might be filled with water without risk of the ship going down or turn- ing over, as she had a great list to starboard and her boiler fires were on the point of being extinguished. This was being effected at 11a.m.
The cause of the fire is unknown.

div.head: THE SUCRERIES.
div.p: The report of the experts, and especially their criticism of the proposals of the con- trollers appointed under the concordat pre- ventif, has given rise to considerable discussion. The opinion is held in some circles that from the point of view of the shareholders a de- claration of bankruptcy will be the best solu- tion of the difficulty. Experts take the line that to speak of the financial reconstruction of the Sucreries is all very well in its way, but that all must depend on the question whether the sugar industry can in future be carried on at a profit. To sell the railways would only hasten the catastrophe, for they are essential to the economic working of the industry. The controllers have, no doubt, submitted their answer to the criticism of the experts to the juge-commissaire, which should prove highly interesting. Meantime the shareholders are about to meet this afternoon, and what their attitude will be, after Thursday's meeting of creditors and the reading of the reports of the experts, is a most interesting problem.

div.head: ACCIDENT TO M.M. STEAMER.
div.p: The homeward bound Messageries Maritimes mail steamer Ofeanien arrived at Suez on Wednesday with a broken shaft. She was moored shortly after in the Port Ibrahim basin, in order to land the mails and passengers. The latter left Suez at 8.30 yesterday evening by special train for Alexandria, where they were transferred to the company's steamer at that port for conveyance to Marseilles.
As the Caledonian is too long for the dry- dock at Suez she will be towed to-morrow to Port Said by the Canal Company's tug Titan, and thence to Marseilles by one of the com- pany’s steamers.

div.head: NOTES FROM THE SUDAN,
div.p: The weather here is still rather oppressive, although we get nice cool nights.
Polo is in fall swing, and we can boast of one of the best grounds in the Sudan.
Kaimakam Hawker Bey, 0.C. of the Camel Corps here, left a few days ago for Suakin, where he takes up his duties as moudir.
The 8th Sudanese Battalion is arriving here shortly relieve the half battalion of the 12th Sudanese, which has left for Wan temporarily.
We have had large swarms of locusts lately passing over the town, and they have done serious damage to the crops in the province.

div.head: HAMBURG-AMERIKA LINE
AMALGAMATION WITH ANGLO-AMERICAN.
div.p: The negotiations between the Anglo-Ameri- can Nile Steamer and Hotel Company and the Hamburg-Amerika Steamships Company have ended satisfactorily, and the contract has just been signed. The terms of the amalgamation are in every way satisfactory to both parties concerned and this morning the shares of the Anglo-American Company conse- quently advanced rapidly and closed at 5 7/8.

It is some time ago since Egypt learnt that the Hamburg-Amerika Steamship Company was desirous of starting a Nile steamer ser- vice and at first it was understood that the venture would be made independently of the companies already established, notably Messrs. Thomas Cook and Son, and the company with which they have just come to terms. Some agitation was evinced and the opinion was expressed in some quarters that German en- terprise should not be allowed the opportu- nity of ousting those companies which had a prior right. The matter was taken np in London, and questions were asked in Parlia- ment, hot, as is so often the case, no definite answer either satisfactory or otherwise was vouchsafed.

Shortly afterwards it was rumoured that the conditions under which Nile traffic is car- ried on were to be changed, and that the changes would in all probability deter any would-be interloper from entering into competi- tion with the established companies. Then we learnt that negotiations for the amalgamation of the Hamburg-Amerika line with the Anglo- American were pending,and later that arrange- ments bad been made for meetings between the directors of the two companies at Paris or Berlin. We have more than once prophesied the result of these negotiations, and our anti- cipations now appear to have been well-founded.

The Anglo-American line is well-known and is yearly making rapid strides; strengthened by the valuable support of the Hamburg- Amerika Company, with the concomitant addition to its capital and consequent increase of its fleet, it cannot fail to progress still more rapidly. What with the yearly increase of Nile traffic there is plenty of scope for two such lines as Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son and the new amalgamation, and we have every hope of seeing a continued improvement in the already excellent service, without either party suffering from the inevitable but healthy competition of its rival.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ANTIQUITIES AT DUBLIN.
div.p: General Lord Grenfell daring his extended military service in Egypt, which commenced in 1882 and ended with his command of the Egyptian forces in 1898, made an interesting collection of antiquities. This collection he has now lent to the Dahlia Museum. It includes a bronze head of the cat-headed goddess Pasht, and a funeral likeness which illustrates the art of portrait-painting twenty centuries ago.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Count A. Gorzaga and the Marehese di San Guilielmo, who recently visited the Colonial Congress at Asmara, have left for Italy.
H. E. the Governor has left for Cairo to spend the Beyram holiday.
Dr. Rucker-Jenisch, German Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General, who has been somewhat indisposed since his return from Europe, is now quite convalescent.

The late British representative on the Public Debt Commission at Cairo is finding his time folly oocupied in the Russian Capital, for while Sir Charles Hardinge is absent from his post at St. Petersburg, for the furtherance, it is sur- mised, of an understanding between En- gland and Russia, Mr. Cecil Edward Spring- Rice, the First Secretary, in charge of affairs in the Russian capital, has bean arranging for the protection of British subjects there in the untoward event of civil commotion. Mr. Spring- Rice may possibly find himself in charge dur- ing an exciting time. St. Petersburg is, or shortly will be, closed to ships by ice, and till the other day, the only line of railway that was working was the St. Petersburg-Moscow line.

Mr Spring Rice is the grandson of the first Lord Monteagle, and was, last year, married to Miss Lascelles, the daughter of Sir Prank, and the charming maitresse de ceans of her father’s Embassy. Her mother was the daughter of Sir James Olliffe, M.D., a practitioner very much in favor, and in fashion, in the Paris of the Second Empire.
Major E. R. 0. Ludlow, D.A.A.G., and Mrs. . Ludlow will proceed on the 80th inst. to Mena Home Hotel where they intend to pass the winter.
Mr. Glymenopoulo is arriving from Europe on the 5th prox. by the Messageries Maritimes steamer. .

The Societe National d’Agriculture de France has made Bogbos Pasha Nubar a foreign member for the mechanical and irri- gation section. Two years ago the society awarded his Excellency its Gold Medal for his steam plough, an award which was quite exceptional.
Mr, J. Bevan, one of the directors of the Anglo-Egyptian Bank, Ltd., is expected at Mona House on the 9th December.

Messrs. Russell and Kerr, chartered account- ants, of Cairo and Alexandria, announce that they have taken into partnership Mr. S. C. Wyatt, A.C.A., and that the firm will be known in future as Russell, Kerr and Wyatt Messrs. Russell and Kerr will continue to reside in Cairo and Alexandria respectively, while Mr. Wyatt is opening a London office of the firm at Moorgate Court, E.C.

Among the latest arrivals at the Eastern Exchange Hotel, Port Said, are : Mr. and Mrs. Colquhoun, Mr. M. King. Mr. D. Cuile, Mr. J. A. Keenly, Mr. Fred. Latinew, Mr. and Mrs. G. Beaman, Mr. and Mrs. D. F. Basden, Mrs. W. I. Luiette, Mr. W. Fretwell, Mr. J. Mc- Gown, Mr. Percy L. Smyth, Mr. J. Pringh, Mr. W. J. Wayte, Mr. McKay, Mr. 0. Gantes, Mr. A. Barton Buckley, Mr. A. L. Farwell, Mrs. C. E. Maltbs, Capt. R. R. Willis, Mr. B. Cavadia. Mr. N. N. Tabet, Mr. L.- J. Eastwood, Mr. W. D. Blakes, Mrs. W. ft Kingaford, Mr. Allen Joseph, Mr. Y. Reynolds, Mr. Anderson, Mr. W. Weber, Mr. A. Stul- ken, Mr. P. Hindlay, Khalib Bey Riad, Sub- Governor of Port Said, Mohamed Bey Rachid, Mr. G. Railston, Mr. S. W. Trafford, Mr. P. P. Higgins. Mr. Littlewood, Mr. H. Cooper, Mrs. F. de Rougement, Miss Owen, Mr. H. Smyth, Mr. J. S. Cowen, Mr. G. N. Malcolm, Mr. Crawley, Miss Dresser.

div.head: NILE TOURISTS.
div.p: The following passengers left Cairo by P.S. Nefertari yesterday, for the Nile trip Mr. and Mrs. Sneath, Master and Miss Sneath Admiral and Miss F.E. Kane, Miss Llewellyn, Misa Jean Greive, Mire D’Aubray, Count Max Marzani, Mr. A. M. Cohen, Miss and Miss D. Rogers, Mr. Chas Royle, Mr. P.V. Davis, Mr. J. Sloan, Mr. John L Low, Mrs. Low, Mr. H. M. Forster, Mr. Colin C. Macaulay, Miss M.A H. Simpson, Misa A.A. Methley, Miss Harding, Miss Cowell, Lt Col. Aberigh Meo- key, Mr. P.W. Early, Mia A. B. Bruce, Mia A. M. Dobie, Mr. and Mr*. Vaughan Wild, Mr. H. E. Bowman, Dr. Grimolbey, Mr. Jos. Fray, Dr. Allen, Mrs. Motley.

div.head: PASSENGER LIST
div.p: Departures
Per S.S Congo of the Messageries Maritimes sailed yesterday for Marseilles.
M. and Mme Mimont M. Rizzo-Noris, M. Manzi.

div.head: The Egpytian Salt and Soda Co. Ltd.
The cal de travers asphalte paving company, Limited.
Maple and Tottenham court road london england
The largest stock of Surplus Books
